prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I tell my girlfriend she can’t bring her friend to my apartment anymore?
A little over a month ago my girlfriend and her parents got into a fight so she came to stay with me until they made up.  I was really clear that this was just temporary until they patched things up.  

It was going fine until she started bringing one of her friends over.   I had met this girl a few times before.  I thought she was ok.  

My girlfriend is like a totally different person around her.   They both get nasty.  Really catty.  There have been a bunch of times that it’s bothered me.  

There was one time I came home and it suddenly got quiet as soon as I came in.  It was awkward so just to break the silence I said something like, “I’m beat” and they both busted out laughing hysterically.   I asked my girlfriend what was so funny and she just told me nothing.  It was kinda obvious that were laughing at my expense, whatever. 

Another time I was in my bedroom and came to the kitchen to make a sandwich.  They were in the living room.  I wasn’t paying attention to what they were saying.  I have no idea what it was about.  I thought it’d be nice to offer to make them some snacks so I started to offer and girlfriend’s friend cut me off and said, “shocker the MAN has to have an opinion about it” in a really nasty way.  I thought to myself “well fuck you too”, but just said “actually nope” and took my sandwich back to my bedroom. 

The situation that sent me over the edge though happened yesterday.   It was my last day off and I wasn’t able to relax much on Monday.   I was in the living room playing a game and they came over.  Girlfriend asked if they could have the room and I go to the bedroom.   I said “nah I’m right in the middle of this, can you guys hang out in the bedroom?”   Friend gave the most sour ducking look and my girlfriend got an attitude.  “It’s just a stupid game, you can play it anytime”.  So I said, “ yeah I can play it anytime and I’m playing it now”.  Friend mumbled something I couldn’t hear and they went to the bedroom.  It’s a small apartment and I could hear them both bitch about me even with the tv on.  

My girlfriend is usually such a sweet and funny person, but when her friend is around it’s like a switch flips and she’s a totally different person.  I don’t get it.   I don’t really want to, I just don’t want to deal with it anymore.  I want to tell her not to bring her friend here anymore.  Also maybe start pushing her to try talking to her parents again.  
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the situation is in the wrong. So the scenario is about a guy who's living with his girlfriend after she had a fight with her parents. She brought her friend over, and he's now considering telling her she can't bring her friend anymore.

First, I need to understand the key points here. The author is concerned about his girlfriend's behavior changing when her friend is around. He gives examples of the friend being rude and his girlfriend acting differently. He's had multiple incidents where the interactions were awkward or unpleasant. The question is if he's in the wrong for wanting to set this boundary.

So, the user thinks the author is in the wrong, but wants my opinion. I need to consider both sides. On one hand, the author is setting boundaries for his own comfort. It's reasonable to have rules about who can come to your home, especially if it's affecting your living environment. On the other hand, maybe the author should communicate more first, like talking to his girlfriend about his concerns before cutting off the friend entirely.

But the author mentions that the girlfriend's friend's presence is causing tension and that the girlfriend acts differently around her. The author might be justified in feeling that his space is being invaded and that the friend's presence is negative. However, maybe the author should have addressed the issue with his girlfriend first instead of deciding unilaterally. 

Also, the situation is temporary, as the girlfriend was staying with him until she made up with her parents. If the friend's presence is part of why they're not making up, maybe pushing her to talk to her parents is a good idea. But the main question is about the friend. 

Is it fair for the author to set that boundary? In a shared living space, people usually have the right to set rules about guests, especially if the guests are causing issues. So the author might have the right to ask the friend not to come over. But maybe he should approach it through communication with his girlfriend first. However, the question is about being in the wrong. If the friend's behavior is disrespectful, then the author isn't in the wrong for protecting his space. 

Alternatively, maybe the author is overreacting, and the girlfriend's friend isn't that bad. But the examples given seem to indicate that the friend is condescending or hostile. The friend's comment about the man having an opinion was dismissive and rude. So the author's feelings are valid.

So, putting it all together, the author isn't in the wrong for wanting to set this boundary. He's justified in protecting his living environment. Therefore, the answer is B (No, the author is not in the wrong).
